Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story:
I watched my younger brother tighten his helmet, his eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, uneven ramp in our backyard. He was determined to master a new skateboard trick, but I could see the risk in every jagged edge and loose board. As his older sibling, I felt a knot of worry twist in my stomach—my parents always said I was responsible for his safety when they weren’t home. But today was Friday, and I was also the imam at our local mosque. The congregation expected me to deliver the Khutbah, a responsibility I never took lightly. 

An invited guest speaker was ready and willing to step in, but I knew some community members would be disappointed if I wasn’t there. My phone buzzed with a reminder: only thirty minutes until the sermon. I glanced at my brother, who was already rolling toward the ramp, and then at the clock. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my presence, each with its own consequences. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the pulpit and the ramp, unable to move.
